item.title: Comments
Formatting
item.description: General Use 4 spaces (no tabs) for indentation Prefer dashes over camelCasing in class names. Do not use ID selectors When using multiple selectors in a rule declarations, give each selector its own line. Put a space before the opening brace { in rule declarations In properties, put a space after, but not before, the : character. Put closing braces } of rule declarations on a new line Put blank lines between rule declarations Avoid the use of !

item.title: Terminology
item.description: Rule Declaration A rule declaration generally consist of one or more selectors, and a list of properties. For example: .class-name { display: block; margin: 0; } Selector A selector matches the element(s) to which the style rules will be applied. Selectors can be any combination of a class name, a HTML attribute as well as psuedo-classes and psuedo-elements. For more details on selectors, see the W3C CSS selectors specification.
